description.narrative: The mission of the Astana CS Hub is to assist the governments of participating countries to enhance the civil service effectiveness

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1.New knowledge on civil service development is delivered to the Hub participating countries 2.Civil servants of the Hub participating countries are capacitated by ACSH to support civil service modernization efforts 3.South-South/East-East and Triangular Cooperation exchanges among Hub participating countries is facilitated

comment.narrative: 1.Lack of access to evidence-based knowledge on civil service development 2.Demand for building the capacity of national and local governments to implement development initiatives in an inclusive and participatory manner 3.Fragmented manner of Civil Service cooperation among the Hub participating countries

1. The regional and international role of the Astana Civil Service Hub is expanded as a globally recognized platform for exchange of knowledge, best practices and innovations in civil service reform, as well as in public service delivery. 2. The civil service institutions and participating countries are empowered and supported through building institutional and human capacity in civil service, thematic researches and comparative analysis, as well as by piloting and introducing innovative approaches and modern solutions in governance, including digitalization. 3. Extension of the ACSH beyond 2020 is successfully negotiated with GOK securing suitability and funding for the next phase.

1. Growing demand for the ACSH’s initiatives is evident by the increasing number of its participating countries rising from 25 to 42 and its institutional partners expanding from 5 to 80 in the past seven years. In 2020 the ACSH has signed three Memorandums of Understanding, bilateral – with Federal Public Service Policy and Support of the Kingdom of Belgium and the Hamad Bin Khalifa University (Qatar), trilateral – with the Agency of the Republic of Kazakhstan for Civil Service Affairs and HR Association of Kazakhstan, as well as and Exchange Letter of Cooperation on the South-South Network for Public Service Innovation launched by the Government of Bangladesh and the UN Office for South-South Cooperation; On 5 March 2020, during the ACSH delegation’s visit to Brussels, bilateral meetings were held- jointly UNDP Brussels Representation Office and the Embassy of Kazakhstan - with the Division for Central Asia, European External Action Service (EEAS) and the European Commission Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development (DG DEVCO). Both meeting counterparts were very much impressed by the activities and achievements of the ACSH and thus expressed their interest to work closely in the field of governance focusing on Central Asia, including Afghanistan. It was agreed to identify the needs of target countries and design a proposal within the New EU strategy for Central Asia (2021-2027); In 2020, partnership with OECD - one of the strategic partners and founders of the ACSH -enhanced further and reached new level; Considering special conditions in 2020 caused by the recent pandemic, ACSH has actively maintained partnership relations with all participating countries, international and national organizations, institutional partners, and other interested parties. Successful cooperation continued and strengthened in particular with representatives from Republic of Azerbaijan, Republic of Belarus, Belgium, Estonia, Georgia, Germany, Republic of Korea, Kyrgyz Republic, Republic of Uzbekistan and Ukraine and with such institutional partners as Association of HR Managers of Kazakhstan, Whiteshield Partners, Nazarbayev University, IIAS and AAPA. The countries and institutional partners have actively participated in activities initiated by the ACSH, conducted joint events and expressed readiness to enhance collaboration in civil service development; The ACSH continued its strategic collaboration with its key national partners, specialized agencies of the participating countries, professional organizations and associations, public administration educational institutions, etc., by initiating and implementing a wide range of activities with them. Their positive feedback demonstrates that the ACSH’s initiatives remain in high demand. Furthermore, the ACSH is continually exploring other sustainability opportunities by expanding its partnerships and networks with other international and regional organizations, and with potential donors. The ACSH received an endorsement for funding from the Republic of Korea to jointly implement a project on innovation in public administration and provision of digital public services through differentiated channels of delivery (2021-2023). 2. COVID-19 outbreak has forced governments to urgently adapt and properly respond to the pandemic.The crisis demonstrated that governments can be agile and adaptive. In this context, the ACSH organized a series events focused on discussion of the latest developments and crisis-induced challenges, including sharing experiences, achievements, lessons learnt, effective and innovative tools in order to contribute to global exchange of practical experiences and knowledge, and enhance further ways of cooperation, including peer to peer learning schemes. Overall, the ACSH conducted up to 30 partnership, capacity building, research, and knowledge management activities in 2020. In total, 3617 civil servants, scholars, and experts from 46 countries, including 2642 participants from Kazakhstan (men 1534 = 42 % and women 2083 = 58 %) benefitted from the ACSH’s partnership, capacity building, research initiatives focused on topics as HRM, digitalization, e-governance, telecommuting, crisis communications etc.; ACSH has launched the Virtual Alliance of practitioners for experience sharing in the context of Covid-19. The digital platform gathers and disseminates existing practices and innovative solutions employed in different countries. Several practical cases studies were provided by the peers, which later were disseminated through ACSH’s channels to all participating countries, including local state bodies. To date, over 10 countries and 20 organizations have contributed to this digital platform, disseminating over 40 cases and articles on existing practices and innovative solutions employed in the region and beyond. For example, the work of the alliance has supported the city of Turkestan in launching an easy-to-use system of online registration of entry, exit and movement of citizens during the COVID-19 lockdown. 3. In close partnership with the UNDP CO and respective bodies of the Government of Kazakhstan, ACSH kept working on further extension and advancement of the current initiatives. As a result, a proposal of the UNDP CO on extending the ACSH initiative for another 3 years, together with the allocation of additional funds in the order of USD 1.2 million annually has received endorsement and the relevant approval processes are ongoing. In order to enable the ACSH to honor its on-going commitments and to implement its outstanding activities uninterruptedly, while the approval process for the new phase is being finalized, the UNDP proposed to the Agency – in its capacity as the Implementing Partner – a twelve-month no-cost extension of the current Project. Such extension was formalized by exchange of letters between UNDP and the Agency.

1. The role of the Astana Civil Service Hub expanded and capitalized on its success as a globally recognized platform for regional cooperation and partnership both domestically and internationally to better exchange knowledge and best practices in civil service reform among Kazakhstan and other countries in the region. 2. The civil service institutions and participating countries are empowered through exchange of knowledge, innovations in research, capacity building activities, expert networking drawn from the Astana Civil Service Hub and benefited from peer-to-peer learning, South-South / East-East and Triangular partnership mechanisms to apply and adapt best practices in civil service excellence.

1. The Astana Civil Service Hub’s participating countries are better informed about global and regional trends in civil service, as well as the innovations and best practices in public service delivery in the region. 2. Civil service institutions of Hub participating countries are empowered via practical leverage on acquired knowledge, training and research skills and expert network drawn from the Hub activities and benefited from peer-to-peer learning and South-South / East-East (SS/EEC) and Triangular Cooperation (TC) exchanges to apply and adapt innovations in civil service excellence.

1. The Hub has expanded to 40 participating countries with Uzbekistan and Montenegro joining the Hub in 2018 and Memorandums of Cooperation/Understanding have been signed, namely with the Ministry of Public Administration of Montenegro, Ministry of Personnel Management of the Republic of Korea, Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration (RANEPA). 2. On 7-9 June 2018, around 130 representatives, the heads of civil service agencies and experts from over 40 countries gathered in Astana to discuss key issues in civil service development within the Hub’s Annual Conference devoted to the civil service excellence in the era of sustainable development goals. It is worth to noting that representatives of Bangladesh, Brazil, Uzbekistan and Montenegro participated at the conference for the first time. The Hub’s key partners, including the UNDP Resident Representative in Kazakhstan Mr. Norimasa Shimomura, Chairman of the Agency of the Republic of Kazakhstan for Civil Service Affairs and Anti-Corruption Mr. Alik Shpekbayev, member of the National Council of the ASPA Mr. Rex Facer, President of the Asian Association for Public Administration Dr. Alex JR. Brillantes in their welcoming speeches stressed the Hub’s role in advancing knowledge sharing on public service excellence. The head of OECD Directorate for Public Administration Mr. Marcos Bonturi in his video speech noticed that OECD was honored to be a strategic partner and one of the founding members of the regional hub. Representatives of key stakeholders, including Director of the Civil Service Bureau of Georgia Ms. Katherine Kardava, Chairman of the Civil Service Council of the Republic of Armenia Mr. Manvel Badalyan, Rector of the Civil Service Academy under the President of Turkmenistan Mr. Alym Annamuradov, and Head of the Law Department of the Agency of Civil Service of Tajikistan Mr. Rajabmurod Tolibov, shared their visions for public service innovations and e-government development. Director for Strategic Policy of the UNDP Bureau for Policy and Programme Support (BPPS) Mr. Pedro Conceicao highlighted that UNDP sees the Hub as one of the prime instruments that contributes towards SDGs. Policy Specialist in Anti-Corruption and Public Administration from the UNDP Istanbul Regional Hub Mr. Irakli Kotetishvili, Manager of the Public Employment and Management project of OECD Governance Directorate Mr. Daniel Gerson, Rector of Academy of Public Administration of Kyrgyzstan Mr. Almaz Nasyrov and representative of the Azerbaijan State Examination Center Ms. Narmin Zeynalova provided their comments regarding future collaboration perspectives. Within the Conference, the participants were presented the updated composition of the Hub’s Steering Committee. 3. Cooperation with the UNDP Istanbul Regional Hub has been strengthened through the meeting of Chairman of the Steering Committee of the Hub and UNDP Deputy Regional Director for Europe and the CIS, on 26 February 2018. The prospects for cooperation in facilitating the civil service modernization and interest in organizing joint events and research activities in the field were identified and discussed. 4. Strong partnership of the Hub was reinforced with the UNDP Bureau for Policy and Programme Support to enhance further cooperation. 5. In line of enhancement of cooperation with the Secretariat of SSN4PSI, the Chairman of the Steering Committee has become a member of the Advisory Board. 6. The representative of the Hub led by the Chairman attended the UN Public Service Forum “Transforming Governance to Realize the Sustainable Development Goals” in Marrakech, on 21-23 June 2018 where the Hub’s future collaboration opportunities were discussed with key partners. The joint capacity building activities with UNDESA Division for Public Institutions and Digital Government to support achieving Sustainable Development Goals and the possibility of signing agreement between the UNDESA and the Hub on developing digital government have been observed. The Hub has demonstrated and been identified as a perfect structure for implementing UNDESA E-Government methodology. 7. The Hub was invited to take part in the Regional Symposium on “Strengthening Capacities of Public Institutions and Developing Effective Partnerships to Realize the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”, which was held from 24 to 26 October 2018 in Incheon and co-organized by the Division for Public Institutions and Digital Government (DPIDG) of the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA), through its Project Office on Governance (UNPOG), with the support of the Ministry of the Interior and Safety of the Government of the Republic of Korea. Representative from the Prime-Minister’s Office have participated at the costs of the Hub and has presented “Development of Digital Government and Innovational Ecosystem in Kazakhstan” at the session on Effective Public Institutions and Digital Government for Advancing the SDGs, while a presentation on the Hub’s activities as a platform for cooperation and capacity building was held at the session on partnership. 8. Institutional partnership with the Agency of the Republic of Kazakhstan for Civil Service Affairs and Anti-Corruption was stimulated for future prospects and developments. In particular, support in implementing a number of significant projects - the Factor and point scale (grading) system, the Common framework of competencies (Competencies Model), the study on "Advancing Civil Service Reform in Kazakhstan: benchmarking against OECD countries" are provided. The Hub has been actively cooperating with the Agency over the years of project implementation. Furthermore, participation in relevant platforms and events for civil servant’s capacity building and enhancement of the Government potential is supported. 9. Partnerships with the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) and Federal Executive Institute (FEI) were enhanced through meeting of the Chairman of Steering Committee with the Director of the OPM and Director of the FEI on 9 March 2018. An active and successful collaboration of the OPM and Hub in the area of civil service development as well as newly elaborated leadership and internship programmes by the FEI were discussed. As a result, Hub organized trainings for high-level representatives of the Government of Kazakhstan to the Leadership Development Programme with study visits to the U.S. Federal, State and Local Governments on 13-17 August 2018. 10. Successful cooperation continued and strengthened with the Embassies of Hub’s participating countries and beyond, in particular with Republic of Belarus, FYR Macedonia, Canada, the Republic of Korea, the People's Republic of China, the United Arab Emirates. The Countries actively participated in activities initiated by the Hub and conducted joint events with the Hub. Once again, the countries expressed readiness to enhance collaboration in the area of civil service developments. 11. As continuous cooperation with the American Society for Public Administration for public service excellence, since 2015 Hub traditionally conducted its panel session in the framework of ASPA’s Annual Conference. This year Hub organized Panel on “Challenges, Issues and Tools for Public Service Excellence in the 21st Century” on 14 March in Denver, USA. ASPA members and Conference participants noted Hub’s contribution to the development of effective systems of civil service. ASPA Executive Director has mentioned that Hub contributed to capacity building efforts for the improvement of the public sector and thus assisted towards the successful implementation of Goals 16 and 17 directly. 12. Strong collaborative partnership agreement reached between The Hub and International Anti-Corruption Academy (IACA) to further initiative and conduct joint activities with involvement of Hub’s participating countries. 13. The Hub’s Roster of Experts has been expanded up to 100 experts with more detailed information and currently available for public access via website. As a result, countries in the region expressed interest in using the Hub roster in their work on civil service reform. 14. The public awareness of the Hub’s major activities was raised by national and international mass and social media through number of media products including press releases, videos, brochure/booklet, visuals and infographics, announcements communicated through the Hub’s website and other social networks. 15. The 3rd Needs Assessment Survey of the ACSH participating countries was conducted and its outcomes were presented at the Annual Conference in June 2018. The findings of the survey provided sufficient information to discern the priority areas of cooperation in civil service management, development and in public service delivery for the next two years. It gauges interest for potential activities supporting civil service development and public service delivery enhancement. 16. Within the Hub’s Annual Conference in June 2018, a series of lectures “Hub Talks” took place for the first time. Ms. Christine Leitner, Senior Advisor of the Center for Economics and Public Administration (CEPA, UK), Mr. Pedro Conceicao, Director for Strategic Policy of the UNDP BPPS, and Mr. Sayasat Nurbek, Independent Expert and Researcher of Kazakhstan talked about the impact of disruptive technologies on public administration and public service delivery. 17. The Hub, the OECD Public Governance Directorate and the Agency of Kazakhstan on civil service affairs and anticorruption completed a joint study benchmarking Kazakhstan’s strategic human resource management (HRM) practices against those in OECD countries. It was the first and unique research that compared Kazakhstan’s Human Resource Management (HRM) practices against those of OECD countries. The results of this research have been outlined in the report “Benchmarking Civil Service Reform in Kazakhstan” (in English and Russian languages). The research presented comparable data on a wide range of policies and practices that help to build a professional, strategic and innovative civil service workforce: delegation arrangements, workforce planning, competency frameworks, recruitment practices, career development, performance and incentives, and public leadership. It serves as a useful guide for civil service practitioners and experts of Kazakhstan, as well as other countries. One of the sessions of the Hub’s Annual Conference in June 2018 was devoted to the trends and innovations in human resource management. Mr. Daniel Gerson from the OECD Governance Directorate presented key findings of a comparative study on Strategic Human Resources Management. 18. The Hub’s participating countries and partners became acquainted with Motivation of civil servants in Kazakhstan, Pakistan and comparative analysis in these two countries published in English and Russian languages. The Hub jointly with the UNDP Global Center for Public Service Excellence in Singapore completed the study and published three reports on the motivational factors of civil servants in Kazakhstan and Pakistan as well as to their comparative analysis. The key goal was to provide a comprehensive picture of the motivational profile of public servants in Kazakhstan. This study examines more generally the attitudes of public servants in Kazakhstan toward their career, the culture and climate of their working environment, and identifies what they see as the biggest constraints and most effective reform instruments to enhance motivation and performance. Findings of the reports, the obstacles highlighted by respondents, as well as suggested ways of improving the performance system in Kazakhstan may help decision-makers in their efforts to professionalize civil service. 19. The 9th and 10th issues of Hub’s International Journal of Civil Service Reform and Practice were published both online and in print versions and have been disseminated among participating countries and partners of the Hub and generated interest from potential authors for the next issue 20. Considering the current political agenda in Kazakhstan, brief analytical memos on Law Enforcement Agencies (police) and Shared Services Centers were prepared by the Hub and shared with the Executive Office of President and the Agency for Civil Service Affairs and Anti-Corruption, respectively. 21. The second round of the Innovative Solutions Scheme was conducted. Overall, 46 applications were received with the focus on Digital Government Innovations. As a result of evaluation by the International selection panel, the following bidders have been identified as winners: IMD Competitiveness Center (Switzerland) with the project “Blockchain: an innovative solution for smart governments” and Digital Solutions Ltd. (Kazakhstan) with the project “E-Practicum: online platform for practical knowledge”. The Innovative Solutions Scheme generated interest of 46 representatives of 17 countries: Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, Egypt, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, South Africa, Switzerland, Tajikistan, Ukraine, UK, USA, and Zambia. 22. The Hub published three brief two-pagers in English and Russian languages: (1) State of Global Affairs in the area of Corruption - Perceptions & Hard Data, (2) Anti-Corruption Policies, and (3) Effective Public Service for SDG Implementation. These knowledge products informed government bodies on best practices in these areas. 23. The Hub provided analytical support to the Government of Kazakhstan in the form of analytical papers and research briefs on global and regional trends on various aspects of civil service development. 24. The Hub together with globally recognized authors finalized and published the book “Public Service Excellence in 21st century” that aimed at focusing on successful initiatives in civil service development. The book combined academic and practitioners’ insights to critically examine the challenges faced by civil service systems in the 21st century. 25. The Hub’s website was improved by developing and adjusting the required technical setting that enabled users of the website to easily view and have access to graphics, updates of the news, e-library, events etc. 26. The Hub participated in the International Forum on Peer-to-Peer learning for effective institutions, which was held at the OECD Headquarters in Paris 13-14 February 2018. The experience of Hub was presented in supporting of public services development in the region. Since 2016, the Peer Learning Alliance, which includes organizations of Azerbaijan, Georgia and Kazakhstan, has been working with the assistance of the Hub. During the Hub’s Annual Conference held in June 2018, the representatives of Estonia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan established a second Peer-to-Peer Learning Alliance on the Development of Electronic Government. The Alliance was created in accordance with the OECD Platform for Effective Institutions methodology and was aimed at experience sharing on public services digitalization among practitioners of seven countries. 27. Another event held within the Hub’s 2018 Annual Conference was a seminar on "Effective matchmaking for public service innovation through South-South Network" was arranged jointly by the South-South Network for Public Service Innovation and the Astana Hub. The workshop aimed to develop a deeper understanding and broader exchange in the Global South by identifying the prospective citizen-centric innovations for better public service. It was the first regional event of the South-South Network in Astana. 28. The Hub hosted an international workshop “Remuneration systems of Civil Servants: Experience of the Countries of Region”, which gathered together representatives of central and local government agencies of Kazakhstan, experts in public administration domain, and civil servants of 10 countries, including Europe, Central Asia and Caucasus. Conference on "System of remuneration of civil servants: experience of the countries of the region" on 16 March in Astana. Workshop participants learned the experience of Kazakhstan, Georgia and Moldova in improving their remuneration system for civil servants and discussed challenges and ways forward. 29. On 18 May in Astana the Hub jointly with Nazarbayev University held workshop on “Estonia’s e-Heath Information System: Experience, Challenges and Perspectives” for Kazakhstani health workers, IT specialists and civil servants. The Hub invited an international expert Dr. Madis Tiik, former Advisor of the Estonian President and one of the developers of the e-health information system, who shared Estonian experience on application of ICTs in delivering medical services. 30. On 28 May the Hub jointly with the Nazarbayev University (NU) conducted a workshop on “Change Management” in Astana for 35 high ranking “Corps A” government officials of Kazakhstan. The event aimed to show the role of politicians and innovators in change management in public sector, as well as to provide the officials with practical ideas in managing changes, leading to excellence and effective implementation. The lecturer was professor Lim Siong Guan, the former Head of the Singapore Civil Service Agency, who was also the Chairman of the Economic Development Board and President of the Singapore Sovereign Wealth Fund Group, GIC. Overall, the participants learned how the government officials should lead changes, achieve excellence and ensure effective implementation; learned about Singapore’s experience in public sector reforms and how they can be applied in the context of Kazakhstan; and considered the role of civil servants as political entrepreneurs and innovators. 31. On 29 May the Hub arranged a seminar on "Economic Diversification and Investment Promotion: Lessons from Singapore" in partnership with the NU for 25 “Corps A” civil servants of Kazakhstan. This one-day program focused on Singapore’s experience in economic development and investment promotion. The lecturer professor Lim Siong Guan shared his experience in industry promotion and development through lessons from Singapore; financial management and investment; and asset management of the country. As the result, the participants learned about how Singapore is industrializing and diversifying its economy; considered the role of fiscal and financial management in supporting the long-term development of the country; and considered the political and practical lessons learned from Singapore’s experience with Kazakhstan’s economy. 32. With the Hub’s support, two civil servants from the Ministry of Information Society and Administration of the FYR Macedonia as one of the Hub’s actively participating countries benefitted from training courses on “Big data analysis in public administration” and “Civil servant critical thinking” organized in Astana by the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Kazakhstan on 24-28 June 2018 and 17-19 September 2018 accordingly. 33. As a result of the Hub’s continued and successful partnership with the US Office of Personnel Management, Federal Executive Institute (OPM/FEI) a five-day Leadership Development Program and study visit to USA was organized for Kazakhstan government officials in August 2018 to explore the U.S. Remuneration (Federal Pay) System, associated policies, classification and appraisal system. 13 representatives from executive bodies comprehensively learned the US remuneration system to further apply best practices in Kazakhstan. 34. The Hub supported and delegated 2 civil servants from Kazakhstan to participate in IACA conference on Anti-Corruption Tailor-Made Training held in Vienna, Austria on 24-26 September 2018. 35. Upon the request from the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Kazakhstan, the Hub greatly contributed to organize lectures on “Geopolitical Trends in Latin America” delivered on 24-28 September 2018, Astana by Dr. Braz da Costa Baracuhy Neto - professor of the Rio Branco Institute. 36. On 5-6 October, the Hub and Nazarbayev University Graduate School of Public Policy (NU GSPP) held a conference on "Contemporary Issues in Public Administration in post-Soviet Eurasia" at Nazarbayev University. The Hub supported and brought together 10 scholars and practitioners from Australia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kazakhstan (Singapore), Kyrgyzstan, Philippines, Poland, Russia, Tajikistan, Ukraine, USA. Researchers, experts and civil service practitioners from more than 30 countries participated in the conference sessions on public administration, civil service reforms, interaction between the civil service, business and civil society, where more than 60 reports were presented. The conference participants shared their research outcomes, knowledge and experience and expanded partnership networks. Some of the conference papers are to be published in the next issues of the International Journal of Civil Service Reform and Practice (March 2019). 37. On 8-12 October 2018 the Hub jointly with the E-Governance Academy (eGA) and the Ministry of Information and Communication of the Republic of Kazakhstan organized a study tour to Estonia for Kazakhstani vice-ministers and deputy mayors, as well as representatives of the Presidential Administration and the Prime Minister’s Office responsible for digitalization. The participants learnt and explored e-government best practices that could be applied in Kazakhstan. 38. The Hub jointly with the Ministry of Information Society and Administration of FYR Macedonia organized an International Conference on “Contemporary Challenges in Public Service and the Role of Partnership for Reaching Solutions” on October 25-26, 2018, in Skopje, FYR Macedonia. The event outlined the role of partnership for overcoming contemporary challenges in public service through presenting the country practices of cooperation for civil service improvement and lessons learnt. 39. On 26-27 November 2018 the Hub in partnership with International Anti-corruption Academy and Agency for Civil Service and Anti-Corruption of the Republic of Kazakhstan organized a Training on “Enhancing Anti-corruption Cooperation in Central Asia and Afghanistan” where participants came from Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan to discuss international efforts, peer exchange, and modern challenges and trends in corruption prevention, and shared lessons learned and good practice examples. 40. The Hub in partnership with the Civil Service College, Temasek Foundation and the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Kazakhstan co-organized the study visit to Singapore for Kazakh civil servants on 19-23 November 2018 to explore the best practices of Public Administration in Singapore. 41. On November 30, the Hub supported and delegated a peer of the P2P Learning Alliance on e-government to participate in the Side Event organized within the Global South-South Development Expo 2018 by the South-South Network for Public Service Innovations, to present the Hub’s Alliance as an innovative networking platform. 42. The Hub further contributed to the capacity-building of civil servants of its participating countries, by allocating 2 scholarships for Mongolian diplomats to pursue a Master’s degree in the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Kazakhstan
